questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with intermittent fever, headaches, and muscle aches. After a detailed history, it is revealed that he recently returned from a trip to a sub-Saharan African country. A blood smear reveals the presence of trypanosomes. The most likely vector responsible for transmitting the pathogen in this case is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tsetse fly

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A) Anopheles mosquito : Incorrect as it is the vector for malaria , caused by Plasmodium species , not trypanosomiasis.
  • • Option A)
  • • Anopheles mosquito
  • • vector for malaria
  • • Plasmodium species
  • • Option C) Aedes mosquito : Incorrect because it is known for transmitting diseases like dengue, Zika, and yellow fever , not African trypanosomiasis.
  • • Option C)
  • • Aedes mosquito
  • • known for transmitting diseases like dengue, Zika, and yellow fever
  • • Option D) Flea : Incorrect as fleas are vectors for diseases like plague and typhus , not African trypanosomiasis.
  • • Option D)
  • • Flea
  • • fleas are vectors for diseases like plague and typhus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vector responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei , the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis . Female tsetse mate just once . After 7–9 days she produces a single egg which develops into a larva within her uterus.
  • ➤ vector responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei
  • ➤ causative agent of African trypanosomiasis
  • ➤ Female tsetse mate just once
  • ➤ 7–9 days she produces a single egg
  • ➤ larva within her uterus.
  • ➤ Ref : Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e, p260, Wikipedia
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Parasitology 2/e, p260, Wikipedia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. He mentions that he recently returned from a camping trip. Stool examination reveals the presence of helminths. Which of the following is least likely to be responsible for autoinfection in this patient?

Ans. D) Hymenolepis diminuta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A) Strongyloides : Incorrect because Strongyloides stercoralis is known for its ability to cause autoinfection in humans .
  • • Option A)
  • • Strongyloides
  • • Strongyloides stercoralis is known for its ability to cause autoinfection in humans
  • • Option B) Taenia solium : Incorrect as Taenia solium can lead to autoinfection, particularly when cysticercosis occurs.
  • • Option B)
  • • Taenia solium
  • • lead to autoinfection, particularly when cysticercosis occurs.
  • • Option C) Hymenolepis nana : Incorrect as Hymenolepis nana can cause autoinfection in humans , especially in immunocompromised individuals.
  • • Option C)
  • • Hymenolepis nana
  • • cause autoinfection in humans
  • • immunocompromised individuals.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autoinfection is seen in CHEST : Cryptosporidium, H.nana, Enterobius, Strongyloides and T.solium.

  • ➤ seen in CHEST

questions.text: A public health officer is investigating a recent increase in malaria cases in a rural area. Which of the following characteristics is most specific to the Anopheles mosquito, the primary vector for malaria?

options.label: C
options.text: Body at an angle when resting

questions.correct_answer: C. Body at an angle when resting
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Body at an angle when resting

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A) Spots on wings : Incorrect, as this is not a specific characteristic of the Anopheles mosquito .
  • • Option A)
  • • Spots on wings
  • • not a specific characteristic of the Anopheles mosquito
  • • Option B) Lay eggs in cluster : Incorrect, many mosquito species lay eggs in clusters , not specific to Anopheles.
  • • Option B)
  • • Lay eggs in cluster
  • • mosquito species lay eggs in clusters
  • • Option D) Palpi as long as proboscis : Incorrect, while this is true for the Anopheles mosquito, it is not as distinctive as the body angle for identification purposes.
  • • Option D)
  • • Palpi as long as proboscis
  • • not as distinctive as the body angle for identification purposes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Anopheles mosquito , identified by a slender body resting at an angle to the surface , features dark spots on wings, outstretched hind legs , and a proboscis aligned in a straight line with the body . Both sexes have maxillary palpi as long as the proboscis , a blunt abdomen tip , and specific peak biting hours , varying in indoor or outdoor preferences. Notable species like A. culicifacies and A. stephensi are vectors of malaria.
  • ➤ Anopheles mosquito
  • ➤ slender body resting at an angle to the surface
  • ➤ dark spots on wings, outstretched hind legs
  • ➤ proboscis aligned in a straight line with the body
  • ➤ Both sexes have maxillary palpi
  • ➤ long as the proboscis
  • ➤ blunt abdomen tip
  • ➤ peak biting hours
  • ➤ Notable species like A. culicifacies and A. stephensi are vectors of malaria.
  • ➤ Ref : Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p316
  • ➤ Ref : Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p316

questions.text: In a rural clinic, a patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and a history of walking barefoot in a region endemic for various parasites. Which of the following parasites is known to have the ability to penetrate intact human skin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Strongyloides

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A) Giardia : Incorrect, as Giardia lamblia is transmitted through contaminated water , not through skin penetration.
  • • Option A)
  • • Giardia
  • • Giardia lamblia is transmitted through contaminated water
  • • Option B) Whipworm : Incorrect, as Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) is transmitted through ingestion of eggs , not skin penetration.
  • • Option B)
  • • Whipworm
  • • Trichuris trichiura
  • • transmitted through ingestion of eggs
  • • Option D) Trichinella : Incorrect, as Trichinella spiralis is acquired by ingesting undercooked meat , not through skin penetration.
  • • Option D)
  • • Trichinella
  • • acquired by ingesting undercooked meat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The unique transmission route of Strongyloides stercoralis , which can penetrate intact human skin , an important factor in its diagnosis and prevention,distinct from the other organisms listed.
  • ➤ unique transmission route of Strongyloides stercoralis
  • ➤ penetrate intact human skin

In contrast, FAncylostoma duodenale (a type of hookworm), Strongyloides stercoralis , and Necator americanus (another hookworm) are known for their ability to penetrate the skin , distinguishing them from Trichinella.

Ionophore-like protein , Phosphatase , and Proteinase , while they may have roles in the amoeba's lifecycle and pathogenesis , are not primarily responsible for mucosal adherence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with fatigue and pallor. He is an avid consumer of sushi and other raw fish dishes. Laboratory tests reveal macrocytic anemia. questions.explanation:

  • • Option A . Man is a single host: Incorrect, as man is the definitive host, but there are intermediate hosts in the lifecycle.
  • • Option A
  • • Man is a single host:
  • • Option B . Iron deficiency anemia: Diphyllobothrium latum primarily causes vitamin B₁₂ deficiency anemia (megaloblastic or macrocytic anemia) rather than iron deficiency anemia.
  • • Option B

  • • Option D. Fish is the definitive host: Fish are intermediate hosts; humans are the definitive hosts.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) causes vitamin B12 deficiency anemia, not iron deficiency anemia. This is due to the tapeworm's ability to absorb vitamin B12 in the intestine. Humans are the definitive hosts with multiple intermediate hosts involved in its lifecycle, not making man a single host. The eggs of Diphyllobothrium are non-operculated and fish serve as intermediate hosts in the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium, while humans are the definitive hosts. Operculated eggs in the stool is diagnostic of an infection with Diphyllobothrium latum

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the clinic with signs of weakness and pallor. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 4.8 g/dL. The child's parents report a history of tarry stools. The family lives in a rural area with poor sanitation. Physical examination shows no significant findings except for pallor. Which parasite is most likely responsible for this child's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • • Option D. Pinworm : Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) is known for causing perianal itching , especially at night, but is not a cause of significant blood loss or anemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, a construction worker in a tropical region, presents with chronic fatigue and weight loss. He reports a history of working barefoot on soil-rich sites. Physical examination reveals pallor, and laboratory tests indicate iron deficiency anemia. Stool examination shows numerous hookworm eggs. What is the average blood loss caused by each Ancylostoma duodenale worm per day?

Ans.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient from a tropical country presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent high fever and progressive swelling of the lower extremities over the past several months. Physical examination reveals significant lymphedema of both legs. Laboratory tests show increased eosinophil count. The patient mentions that these symptoms started after he noticed frequent mosquito bites during his work in rural areas. Based on the patient's history and clinical findings, which worm is most likely responsible for his lymphatic obstruction?

Ans.

Explanation:

  • • children
  • • Option D) Tapeworm - Tapeworms generally cause gastrointestinal symptoms and, in some cases, systemic infections , but they are not known to cause lymphatic obstruction.

  • • Tapeworm
  • • gastrointestinal symptoms
  • • systemic infections

Educational Objective:

The increased eosinophil count also supports the diagnosis of a parasitic infection.
